properties.title: Aditi Indian Cuisine replaces an old French favorite and does so with verve
properties.desc: Aditi for me qualifies as a stand-out amongst all the other family-owned Indian restaurant contenders in the Mission.

properties.title: AL's Deli: Mash-Up or Mish-Mash?
properties.desc: AL’s Deli is the offspring of AL’s Place – yes, the one voted Best New Restaurant in America in 2015 by Bon Appetit.

properties.title: At Alnico, brunch is served!
properties.desc: They’re calling it a brunch pop-up with Asian-fusion flare, but I hope it stays and moves into dinner territory, too.

properties.title: At Ritu, chef moves deliciously from popular food truck to brick-and-mortar
properties.desc: Ritu is a solid addition to the myriad, more traditional Indian restaurants in the Mission.

properties.title: Bao SF: A dedicated dumpling house in the Mission
properties.desc: The arrival of Bao SF brought me such joy! As far as I know, the Mission didn’t have a dedicated dumpling house before now.

properties.title: Base Camp: Hike on up and get your Nepalese fix on!
properties.desc: Well, here we go: another ballsy restaurateur, opening a new Nepalese restaurant in the middle of a pandemic!

properties.title: Biriani House: More Indian in the Hood!
properties.desc: Biriani House is owned by five brothers who had the guts to open a new restaurant in the middle of a pandemic.

properties.title: Chic n' Time: When it's time for chicken, try this Valencia spot
properties.desc: A new-ish, kind-of-fast-foody, Asian-fusion place fixated on chicken that opened up in the old Burger Joint space.

properties.title: Curry Up Now: Curry in a Hurry!
properties.desc: I had the idea that it was a fast-casual, kind of fusiony Indian place (tikka masala burritos, etc.) but I was pleasantly surprised.

properties.title: Dancing Yak: Nepalese in the Mission
properties.desc: Momos are Nepal’s gift to the dumpling world (or more accurately, originally Tibet’s gift), and what a gift. These were divine.

properties.title: Do your part to drum up our economy, while you eat!  Bon, Nene and Beretta
properties.desc: Beretta has been around forever and a day, usually attracting a lively, young crowd with its heated outdoor seating and extensive cocktail list.

properties.title: Do your part to drum up our economy, while you eat!  Bon, Nene and Beretta
properties.desc: A serene little space serving the locals Japanese small plates, breakfast, lunch, and dinner, it definitely has that neighborhood-gem vibe to it.

properties.title: El Sabor de San Miguel: Maya de Guatemala
properties.address: El Sabor De San Miguel, 3263 Mission St, 94110
properties.desc: The Mission has its share of restaurants that hail from the Yucatan region of Mexico, but as far as I know, this is the only one we have from Guatemala.

properties.title: Finding Mission District pupusas that take me back to my mother's kitchen
properties.desc: They only use Salvadoran cheese, so points for authenticity. The pupusas were very warm and had a nice, light sear.

properties.title: Finding Mission District pupusas that take me back to my mother's kitchen
properties.desc: Balompie Café — a quaint, soccer-themed restaurant — has been kicking it in the Mission for 32 years. Their pupusas are the main attraction.

properties.title: Finding Mission District pupusas that take me back to my mother's kitchen
properties.address: La Santaneca de la Mission, 2815 Mission St, 94110
properties.desc: Their pupusas were well toasted, had a nice sear, and were an eye-catching golden hue.

properties.title: Finding Mission District pupusas that take me back to my mother's kitchen
properties.desc: I saved their pupusas for last and I have to say, I was disappointed. They were still tasty but definitely not as fulfilling as when I first tried them.

properties.title: Finding Mission District pupusas that take me back to my mother's kitchen
properties.desc: Panchitas broke a lot of the rules, but their pupusas were so tasty that I could look past these shortcomings.

properties.title: Fiore Caffé: Comfort Food to Go
properties.desc: Fiore Caffé, a sweet, corner Italian cafe that we’d never tried — very local, family-owned, apparently very much beloved by the neighborhood.

properties.title: Flour + Water Pizzeria – A pie to be proud of
properties.desc: The epitome of what pizza should be: Crispy, blistered, juicy, bendy… everything just played together so nicely.

properties.title: Foreign Cinema, by way of Laszlo
properties.desc: Laszlo is now a shiny, squeaky-clean, bona fide “upscale” Mission bar.

properties.title: Foreign Cinema, by way of Laszlo
properties.desc: Foreign Cinema, way back in 1999, opened its doors as one of the very earliest gentrifying restaurants in the Mission.

properties.title: Get out there and order in! More takeout and delivery in the Mission reviews: Prubechu and Castillito Yucateco
properties.desc: Everything was very tasty, and this is quite possibly our new go-to for Yucatecan food.

properties.title: Get out there and order in! More takeout and delivery in the Mission reviews: Prubechu and Castillito Yucateco
properties.desc: We had fantastic fried chicken, red rice, pork belly, roasted assorted veg, their wonderful pickled veg, and finadenne, Guam’s famous vinegary dipping sauce that goes on everything.

properties.title: Heirloom Café is back with pizza and vino!
properties.desc: I’ve always considered Heirloom Café a neighborhood gem, one that’s known by a loyal few who treasure the location, the look of it, the feel of it, of course the food, and perhaps most of all, owner Matt Straus.

properties.title: Hell's Ramen: No Fury
properties.desc: Actually, Hell’s Ramen does have some fury, quite a bit of it, waiting to be unleashed on your tastebuds.

properties.title: Il Pollaio – North Beach invades the Mission
properties.desc: Il Pollaio, a revered fixture in North Beach (circa 1984), is an anomaly of grilled meats in a neighborhood awash in pasta, and just opened a second location in the Mission.

properties.title: Jay's Cheesesteak: if you can't go to Philly …
properties.desc: Jay’s Cheesesteak – yet another institution in the Mission. Do you ever get the feeling that we’re just full of them?

properties.title: JoyRide Pizza: Detroit's in the house!
properties.desc: Remember: A hot slice in the hand is always a good treat.

properties.title: Keep eating locally: Lers Ros and Rosamunde
properties.desc: Is there a better time than now to have some grilled dogs? What’s more comforting than something grilled, nestled in a bun, that you eat with your hands?

properties.title: Keep eating locally: Lers Ros and Rosamunde
properties.desc: One of the best Thai places around.

properties.title: Khamsa: Moroccan in the Mission
properties.desc: The exterior feels like you’re walking into an office building. I’m not going to lie, it’s soulless from the outside. It feels wrong to go here. But go.

properties.title: Kimbara: there's never enough Peruvian
properties.desc: Besides the wait on the steak, service was warm, attentive and glitch-free. The food was all pretty stellar, too, so Kimbara is not suffering from opening jitters.

properties.title: Komaaj: Persian in the house!
properties.desc: If I’m not mistaken, Komaaj may be the only Persian restaurant in the Mission since … ever?

properties.title: La Santaneca: Get your pupusa on!
properties.desc: La Santaneca is ready to serve up what we all need the most right now: Comfort and a hug – in the form of a fluffy, gooey, warm, delicious disk of griddled corn and cheese: the pupusa.

properties.title: La Traviata: help keep old-school Italian alive in the Mission!
properties.desc: La Traviata has been around almost 40 years, and it’s the Mission’s only real “red sauce” Italian place, complete with tablecloths, opera music, and celebrity photos on the walls.

properties.title: Lazy Bear is Awake from Hibernation!
properties.desc: Overall, we found the food probably not worth that long of a wait. Perhaps during less busy times, I’d try something else off the menu.

properties.title: Lolinda now offering family meals to go!
properties.desc: Everything was delicious, with the excellent quality we always expect and receive from Lolinda.

properties.title: Lolinda redux: luxe dining in your home
properties.desc: Sometimes, the food you get from delivery or pick-up doesn’t hold up very well on the trek to your home. But we decided to go ahead, counting on Lolinda to come through for us. HOLY COW, DID THEY EVER.

properties.title: Marlena brings beautiful food near Precita Park
properties.desc: With food this innovative, delicious, and visually stunning, I plan to make it a habit to visit each season.

properties.title: Mission Chinese: still keeping on
properties.desc: It really seems to fit the mood of the moment, hunkering down at home with some good old Chinese take-out, the Mission Chinese Food way.

properties.title: Newkirk's – East Coast sandwiches in the Mission!
properties.desc: My first foray into this land of melty goodness was the BEC – the classic bacon, egg and American cheese on a perfectly squishy, poppy-seed roll.

properties.title: NoodleMania goes to Flour + Water
properties.desc: Everything went as others told me it would, and I mean everything.
properties.byline: by Annika Hom and Mark Rabine

properties.title: NoodleMania goes to Mau
properties.desc: The noodles practically jumped onto my fork and clung to it, not in a mass, but each with an irrepressible desire to be lifted clean up to my mouth and taken in.
properties.byline: by Annika Hom and Mark Rabine

properties.title: NoodleMania goes to Ushio
properties.desc: I wish you had warned me not to eat ramen while watching the NBA finals unless wearing a bib or hazmat suit.
properties.byline: by Annika Hom and Mark Rabine

properties.title: Nopalito's 18th Street take-out window
properties.desc: More Mexican food in the Mission? Hell yeah. A quality takeout joint during the pandemic? Smart move.

properties.title: Obispo: A Caribbean Rum Palace in the Mission
properties.desc: Obispo is a rum mecca, and the food that goes with it could well have been an afterthought, but nothing about these dishes plays second fiddle to the cocktail program.

properties.title: On the Mission ramen trail: Orenchi Beyond or beyond over?
properties.desc: The space is invitingly open, and you can see the cauldrons bubbling away in the steamy, glass-enclosed kitchen.

properties.title: Pho on Bryant – your neighborhood pho and dim sum fix
properties.desc: Serving a combination of Vietnamese pho and other big-bowled noodle soups and Chinese dim sum, Pho on Bryant seems to be building up its clientele slowly but steadily.

properties.title: Pica Pica Arepa Kitchen is back!
properties.address: Pica Pica Arepa Kitchen, 401 Valencia St, 94103
properties.desc: Pica Pica specializes in the venerable Venezuelan snack food arepas, as well as their more crepe-like cousin, cachapas.

properties.title: Puerto Alegre: old stand-by, still going strong
properties.desc: A beloved family-owned-and-run institution, in the Mission for over 45 years, known for their strong margaritas and a lively family atmosphere.

properties.title: Rating the Mission's Ramen: Coco's Ramen
properties.desc: Coco’s is warm and cozy inside and abuts a sushi restaurant with a walkthrough doorway between the two spaces. You know, for when you want a raw fish bang-bang after stuffing yourself with broth and noodles.

properties.title: Reem's California: Lebanese street food!
properties.desc: Reem’s California is a fast-casual restaurant serving Lebanese street food that opened in the Mission just before the pandemic started, and then began offering big family platters of food once the shutdown hit.

properties.title: Restaurant Review: Great Gold – what's in a name?
properties.desc: They offer a family-style dinner with all the fixings, just like your nonna used to make. But I’m afraid we’re not going to rush back just yet.

properties.title: Review: Comfort food at Luna, now without the Park
properties.desc: A good brasserie is something the Mission needs. Despite the missteps, I’m hoping they can elevate the genre and become a real neighborhood destination.

properties.title: Review: Dear Inga – A love letter to your Oma
properties.desc: Elevated, yet rustic, babushka comfort food. It blends modern touches with old techniques of fermentation and smoke, with seemingly meticulous attention to detail.

properties.title: Review: Ernest is a new culinary jewel in the Mission's crown
properties.desc: The menu has a kind of American/Asian upscale comfort food vibe; the food sounds fancy, but it also feels very familiar.

properties.title: Review: Lupulandia Brewing – Tijuana en La MisiÃ³n!
properties.desc: The food is contemporary and playful, and not what you’d expect from your standard taqueria — or from a brewpub, for that matter.

properties.title: Review: PizzaHacker: not a hack job
properties.desc: PizzaHacker touts itself as having brought forth a pizza baby by way of New York City and Napoli, by a Jew from Ohio.  Those are quite the credentials!

properties.title: Sanguchon finally opens in the Mission!
properties.desc: Ever since I first tried a delectable pork sandwich from one of their trucks in the Financial District, I’ve been dreaming of the day… and, lucky us, they opened in the Mission!

properties.title: Serrano's Pizza & Pasta: the tried and true
properties.desc: The thing we love about their pizza is the good, chewy crust, and the juiciness of the toppings (i.e. just the perfect amount of grease!).

properties.title: SF Chickenbox in The Brew Coop – Could this be the Best Fried Chicken Yet?
properties.desc: I’m not going to lie; I wasn’t prepared to be blown away. But this chicken is sublime.

properties.title: Shabu House: A little piece of Clement Street in the Mission!
properties.desc: Very well-known to the young and/or Asian cognoscenti, Shabu House is well on its way to becoming extremely popular in our neighborhood.

properties.title: Support Our Mission Restaurant: Etcetera Wine Bar and Venga Empanadas
properties.desc: Etcetera has a lively little menu, with their specialty being flammenkueche, an Alsatian, very thin, flatbread/pizza type of thing, typically spread with creme fraiche, bacon and thinly sliced onions.

properties.title: Support Our Mission Restaurant: Etcetera Wine Bar and Venga Empanadas
properties.desc: Venga specializes in hand-made Argentinian empanadas. Theirs were super tasty and satisfying, arriving to us nice and hot, with flaky, tender crusts.

properties.title: Support your local restaurants – order food for takeout/delivery
properties.address: The Liberties Bar & Grill, 998 Guerrero St, 94110
properties.desc: It was very tasty and, although it wasn’t as nicely plated as I’m sure it is under normal circumstances, it was a very carbalicious, comforting meal on a rainy evening.

properties.title: Tacolicious: Mother-Effin Chicken Dinner!
properties.desc: This much food was enough for another whole meal the next day for the two of us.

properties.title: Tacos El Patron: like a boss!
properties.address: Tacos El Patron, 1500 S Van Ness Ave #100, 94110
properties.desc: I think this corner of the Mission was just crying out for a taqueria to call its own. Here’s hoping that this is the place that sticks.

properties.title: Tahini: Middle Eastern fast food that tastes homemade
properties.desc: Fresh food, inexpensive, and cat videos. What’s not to love?

properties.title: Takeout at Pizzeria Delfina: birthed in the Mission
properties.desc: While Pizzeria Delfina now has several locations around the city, it all started here, and it’s a neighborhood favorite with good reason.

properties.title: That's It Market and Mission Bar – an unholy, delicious alliance
properties.desc: If you’re not familiar with one of the Mission’s best old-school dive bars, now’s your chance!

properties.title: That's It Market and Mission Bar – an unholy, delicious alliance
properties.desc: Our favorite bar of yesteryear (aka, March 2020), Mission Bar, is partnering with its next-door neighbor, liquor store/kitchen That’s It Market, to offer food and cocktails to its patrons.

properties.title: Troje: a silo of good eats
properties.desc: This visit was so much better than the first, and we’re always happy when a restaurant redeems itself.

properties.title: Voodoo Love brings delicious Creole to the Mission
properties.desc: Hot DAMN, it’s an all-star listing. I think they may have even expanded the menu since we were last there, ensuring we’ll be back.

properties.title: West of Pecos: Tex-Mex in the Mission
properties.desc: This is straight-up Southwestern fare, with standards like fajitas, queso and chips, and good ol’ San Antonio-style puffy tacos.

properties.title: World of Noodles and Banh Mi: A Little Too Much to Swallow?
properties.desc: World of Noodles has quite the variety of noodles, for sure, blurring the lines between Japan, Vietnam and China.

properties.title: Yoji Sushi: more sushi in the Mission!
properties.desc: The fish was quiveringly fresh — beautiful, bright jewels over room-temperature rice — and more than plentiful.

properties.title: You're going to get sick of your own cooking: Takeout at Monk's Kettle and Mission Curry House
properties.desc: A local tavern with 28 beers on tap, 150 bottled, and gastro-pubby food, Monk’s Kettle has become an institution.

properties.title: You're going to get sick of your own cooking: Takeout at Monk's Kettle and Mission Curry House
properties.desc: All very warming and delish. And socially distant!  Mmmmmomos…
